. Chop and soften in water, then

while stirring.

Afterward, strain and place the petals of one thousand
into the oil. Rub your hands with fragrant

and stir repeatedly.

Let stand overnight, then strain through a cloth. Store in a vessel smeared with honey.

skhoinos.definition: A rush or reed. Most scholars identify this as lemongrass (Cymbopogon schoenanthus).

elaion.definition: Olive oil, typically specifically 'omphacium' or unripe olive oil in perfume contexts for its stability.

rhoda.definition: Roses. The specific species is debated, but Rosa gallica or Rosa damascena are primary candidates.

meli.definition: Honey. Used here likely to prevent adhesion or as a fixative agent.

hepsein.definition: To boil or seethe. Indicates hot maceration process.

quotes.author: Dioscorides, Mat. Med. 1.77
quotes.text: The best is that from Troglodytice, pale, somewhat greenish, with a certain oiliness, smooth, and pure.

identifications.name: Opopanax resin
identifications.note: Note: 'Sweet myrrh' or 'bisabol myrrh' may refer to this species.

source.citation: Manniche, L. (1999). Sacred Luxuries: Fragrance, Aromatherapy, and Cosmetics in Ancient Egypt. Cornell University Press.

identificationData.notes: This identification is widely accepted in the scholarly literature. Manniche provides extensive botanical and historical evidence for the equation of Greek σμύρνα with the resin of Commiphora myrrha.

productData.name: Myrrh Resin
productData.description: Aromatic resin harvested from trees of the genus Commiphora, native to the Horn of Africa and Arabian Peninsula.

profile.evolution: Opens sharp and medicinal, almost bitter. Within minutes, softens to a warm, honeyed amber that persists for hours.
profile.comparable: Drier than labdanum, less sweet than benzoin. Shares balsamic notes with frankincense but darker, more complex, more medicinal.

availability.details: Can be sourced from essential oil suppliers and specialty incense vendors. Look for "Commiphora myrrha" specifically; other species (C. guidottii, C. erythraea) have different scent profiles.

commiphoraData.name: Commiphora myrrha
commiphoraData.image: Image: thorny tree in arid landscape
commiphoraData.description: Small, thorny tree native to the Horn of Africa and the Arabian Peninsula. Produces aromatic resin when the bark is wounded. The resin exudes as a pale yellow liquid that hardens into reddish-brown tears. Trees are typically tapped after five years of growth.
commiphoraData.nativeRange: Ethiopia, Eritrea, Somalia, Djibouti, Yemen, Oman

externalResources.name: Kew Plants of the World Online

processData.name: Enfleurage
processData.description: A technique for extracting fragrance from delicate flowers by pressing them into fat or oil. The aromatic compounds transfer slowly over hours or days. The Greek term ἐξιποῦν literally means "to press out."

variations.name: Cold enfleurage
variations.description: Flowers pressed into solid fat (traditionally lard or tallow) at room temperature. Fat is replaced repeatedly until saturated.

variations.name: Hot enfleurage (maceration)
variations.description: Flowers steeped in warm oil. The heat accelerates extraction but may alter delicate notes.

variations.name: Multiple infusions
variations.description: Fresh flowers added repeatedly to the same fat/oil, building intensity. Dioscorides describes up to seven infusions for rose oil.

processData.notes: The ancient terminology is not always consistent. Dioscorides uses ἐξιποῦν and ἐκθλίβειν somewhat interchangeably. Context usually clarifies whether cold or hot infusion is meant.

toolData.name: Mortar and Pestle
toolData.description: A vessel and tool used for crushing, grinding, and mixing ingredients. Essential for breaking down resins, barks, and tough plant materials before extraction.

termsList.def: Myrrh; a resinous gum used in perfumes and incense.
Olive oil; the standard liquid fat base for perfumes.
Roses; the flowers, usually macerated in oil.
Rush or reed; likely Camel Grass or Lemongrass.
Honey; used to treat vessels or thicken mixtures.
A thorny shrub with fragrant wood, possibly Camel’s Thorn.

ingredientsList.name: Cardamom
ingredientsList.def: Aromatic seeds with warm, spicy-sweet scent.

ingredientsList.name: Cassia
ingredientsList.def: Bark with cinnamon-like aroma, more pungent than true cinnamon.

ingredientsList.name: Cinnamon
ingredientsList.def: Aromatic bark with warm, sweet, woody scent.

ingredientsList.name: Myrrh Resin
ingredientsList.def: Aromatic resin with warm, balsamic, slightly medicinal scent.

ingredientsList.name: Omphacium Olive Oil
ingredientsList.def: Oil from unripe olives, preferred for its low scent profile.

ingredientsList.name: Rose Petals
ingredientsList.def: Fresh or dried petals used for enfleurage.

ingredientsList.name: Lemongrass
ingredientsList.def: Citrus-scented grass used as an aromatic.

ingredientsList.name: Honey
ingredientsList.def: Sweet viscous fluid produced by bees.

ingredientsList.name: Labdanum
ingredientsList.def: Sticky brown resin with a deep, amber scent.

ingredientsList.name: Saffron
ingredientsList.def: Dried stigmas of the crocus flower.

worksData.title: De materia medica
worksData.author: Pedanius Dioscorides
worksData.description: The primary source for pharmacology and medical botany for over 1,500 years. Books 1 and 2 cover aromatics and oils.

worksData.title: De odoribus (On Odors)
worksData.author: Theophrastus
worksData.description: A short treatise dealing specifically with perfumes, their ingredients, and manufacturing processes.

worksData.title: Naturalis Historia
worksData.author: Pliny the Elder
worksData.description: An encyclopedic work. Book 13 discusses trees and perfumes.

peopleData.name: Pedanius Dioscorides
peopleData.bio: A Greek physician, pharmacologist, and botanist, employed in the Roman army. Author of De materia medica.

peopleData.name: Theophrastus
peopleData.bio: Successor to Aristotle in the Peripatetic school. Often called the 'father of botany'.

peopleData.name: Tapputi-Belat-Ekallim
peopleData.bio: Considered the world's first recorded chemist, mentioned in a cuneiform tablet from Babylonia.

dioscoridesDetail.name: Pedanius Dioscorides
dioscoridesDetail.bio: Greek physician and pharmacologist, author of De materia medica, the most influential pharmacological text of antiquity. Served as a military physician, possibly under Nero. His work on aromatics and perfumes in Book 1 remains our most important ancient source for perfume recipes.

seanDetail.name: Sean Coughlin
seanDetail.affiliation: Institute of Philosophy, Czech Academy of Sciences
seanDetail.bio: Sean Coughlin is a historian of science and philosophy specializing in ancient Greek and Roman science. He leads the Alchemies of Scent project, which combines philological analysis with chemical replication to understand ancient perfumery.

publications.title: Coughlin, S. (2024). "Ancient Perfume Reconstruction: Methodologies and Challenges."
Coughlin, S. & Graff, D. (2023). "The Scent of the Past: Recreating the Mendesian."

materiaMedicaDetail.title: De materia medica
materiaMedicaDetail.description: Encyclopedic pharmacological treatise covering approximately 600 plants, 35 animal products, and 90 minerals. Book 1 contains extensive material on aromatics and perfumes, making it our primary source for ancient Greek perfume recipes.

editions.name: Wellmann (1907)
editions.desc: Standard critical edition. Reference system: book.chapter

editions.name: Sprengel (1829)
editions.desc: Earlier edition. Reference system: book.chapter (numbering differs)
